ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Great overview of the historiography and main themes/tensions in the literature

I learned a tremendous amount about the historiography of slavery and abolition in the Atlantic world. I also learned how to write comprehensively yet succinctly about a number of texts for both book reviews and historiography papers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strength--great balance between older/classic literature and brand new literature, not every class manages to cover both

I thought we covered incredibly important topics and I gained important training in how discuss texts in conversation and across time. I think it would have been useful to have more comprehensive question posts as opposed to comment posts.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes--great way to ground yourself in the literature of slavery and abolition.
Yes, it was very well structured and interdisciplinary in its approach
Yes - I think this course if vital for any students studying slavery, abolition, or the 19th century Atlantic world.
